rsbNotes.title: Jer 34–36
rsbNotes.text: 34:1–36:32 These chapters narrate scenes of rejection of the word of the Lord that led to final judgment on Judah. King Zedekiah is condemned for going back on his promise to free slaves (ch. 34), and the people of Judah are reproved for failing to learn a lesson from the example of the faithful Rechabites (ch. 35). King Jehoiakim rejects Jeremiah’s message and burns the prophet’s scroll (ch. 36).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 35:2
rsbNotes.text:
35:2 house of the Rechabites. Most of what is known of this clan is in this chapter.

house of the Lord . . . chambers. These rooms were used for storage (1 Kin. 6:5; Neh. 13:4, 5).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 35:3
rsbNotes.text: 35:3 Jeremiah. One of two persons other than the prophet himself named “Jeremiah,” mentioned in the book (see 52:1).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 35:4
rsbNotes.text: 35:4 man of God. Another name for a prophet (1 Kin. 12:22).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 35:6–7
rsbNotes.text: 35:6, 7 The vow taken by Jonadab the son of Rechab commits his descendants to a nomadic life, with impermanent lodging and abstaining from wine. This life was a voluntary commitment not required by the Mosaic law (Deut. 6:10, 11; 7:13).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 35:19
rsbNotes.text: 35:19 shall never lack a man to stand before me. See 33:17, 18. Such a promise might be expected for a king, and even for priests, but not for the obscure Rechabites. It is used here to contrast ominously with what Jehoiakim and the Davidic dynasty can expect.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 36:1
rsbNotes.text: 36:1 fourth year of Jehoiakim. That is, 605 b.c., the year of Nebuchadnezzar’s first move against Jerusalem (25:1 note).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 36:2
rsbNotes.text: 36:2 Take a scroll and write on it. The present account is an important guide to understanding how prophetic books were written. Jeremiah’s oracles were spoken over a long period (25:3), and are here gathered into a collection (Is. 8:16 and note).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 36:4
rsbNotes.text: 36:4 Baruch. This is the second mention of Jeremiah’s scribe (32:12). His activity suggests that he had a role in compiling the Book of Jeremiah.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 36:5
rsbNotes.text: 36:5 I am banned. This statement probably means he was banned from the temple area because of his unpopularity with the authorities (26:2–11).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 36:9
rsbNotes.text: 36:9 In the fifth year . . . the ninth month. That is, December, 604 b.c.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 36:21
rsbNotes.text: 36:21 Jehudi. Baruch is no longer the reader, presumably being in hiding (v. 19). The absence of Jeremiah and Baruch focuses Jehoiakim’s response on the words themselves.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 36:23
rsbNotes.text: 36:23 the entire scroll was consumed in the fire. The contrast with Josiah could not be stronger (2 Kin. 22:11–13).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 36:28
rsbNotes.text: 36:28 Take another scroll. God’s word cannot be invalidated by the destruction of a scroll.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 36:30
rsbNotes.text: 36:30 Jehoiakim . . . shall have none to sit on the throne of David. His son Jehoiachin’s rule lasted only a few months (22:30 note; 2 Kin. 24:8).
